clinical_study.brief_title: Prospective Phase II Trial on Prophylactic Perihepatic Lymphadenectomy in Patients With Colorectal Cancer With Liver Metastasis
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Phase II Trial on Prophylactic Perihepatic Lymphadenectomy in Patients With Colorectal Cancer With Liver Metastasis

brief_summary.textblock: Objective: To evaluate the role of regional lymphadenectomy in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis. Background: Lymph node status is 1 of the most important prognostic factors in oncologic surgery; however, the role of lymph node dissection remains unclear for colorectal cancer liver metastasis.

detailed_description.textblock: Lymph node status is a definite prognostic factor in oncologic surgery and significantly affects long-term survival, as reported by the tumor staging system of the International Union Against Cancer (IUCC), which is the most widespread classification of malignant tumors worldwide. Regional lymphadenectomy is already the standard procedure that completes hepatic resection in the case of carcinoma arising from the extrahepatic bile duct. However, the indication, extent, and role of lymph node excision are still a matter of discussion, and no clear guidelines exist in patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis.

secondary_outcome.measure: To evaluate prognostic significance of perihepatic LN involvement with overall survival and disease free survival

intervention.description: Hepatic pedicle lymph node dissection according to the protocol of the prospective multicentric study.Namely the six main groups of lymph nodes removed (HA,hepatic artery; CA, celiac axis; BD, common bile duct).

study_pop.textblock: Biopsy confirmed colorectal cancer with liver metastasis

clinical_study.keyword: colon neoplasm, rectal neoplasm, liver metastasis
